Yes, here are some examples of Ray Charles' activism outside of his music:

1. In 1961, Ray Charles refused to perform at a segregated concert in Georgia and canceled the show. He then wrote a letter to Eisenhower urging him to enforce the Supreme Court's decision to end segregation.

2. Ray Charles was a vocal supporter of the Civil Rights Movement and performed at numerous benefit concerts to raise money for organizations such as the NAACP, the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, and the Congress of Racial Equality.

3. Charles was a financial contributor to the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC), which worked to end segregation and racism in the South.

4. Charles also testified before Congress in support of copyright reform for recording artists, arguing that they deserved greater control over their work and compensation.

5. In 1979, Charles participated in the Musicians United for Safe Energy concert in support of anti-nuclear activism.

Overall, Ray Charles was a passionate and committed activist who used his platform to fight for social justice and equality, both in his music and his personal life.
